texts.shortText:
Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are small, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

This unusually large species has a very stocky, compressed body and blunt, rounded head bearing a large mouth and thin lips with vertical corrugations. The dorsal fin has 32–34 spines and 9–14 rays, the first 3 spines being raised into a slight crest, followed by a shallow notch before the 4th spine. Colour mottled brown or reddish with broken darker bars that extend onto the dorsal and pectoral fins. Usually cheek bars radiating form below eyes. Eyes with a circle of radiating lines around the iris.
Unusually large, reaching at least 37 (some report 50) cm total length.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Eastern Cape.
A rare species usually associated with algae, uncommon in intertidal. Stagnant and well camouflaged. No other details known.
Diet of this species has not been studied, but the large mouth and sluggish habits suggest that it is probably an ambush predator capable of taking larger prey.

Species-specific details unknown, but all clinids are livebearers, males copulating with females and fertilizing the eggs internally with their intromittent organs. Juveniles develop inside the females’ ovaries and in most species the live young are born in spring, have a short planktonic life then settle on the bottom.
The large size, blunt head, wide mouth with its corrugated lips and notch after third spine on the dorsal fin identify this species.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 396).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 764).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 62).
